Submodules¶

scheduler.admin module¶

This module controls the admin page for django. This is mainly for the superuser to alter data in the database.

class scheduler.admin.PlayerAdmin(model, admin_site)¶

Bases: django.contrib.auth.admin.UserAdmin

Controls the fields for creating a user in the admin page. This is also why the admin has the ability to set permissions

add_fieldsets = ((None, {'classes': ('wide',), 'fields': ('username', 'password1', 'password2')}), ('User', {'fields': ('first_name', 'last_name', 'email', 'battlenetID', 'university', 'role', 'skillRating')}), ('Permissions', {'fields': ('is_active', 'is_staff')}))¶
list_display = ['battlenetID', 'username', 'first_name', 'last_name', 'university']¶
media¶
model¶

alias of scheduler.models.Player

class scheduler.admin.TeamAdmin(model, admin_site)¶

Bases: django.contrib.admin.options.ModelAdmin

Sets up the fields for creating a team. Uses django’s default form aside from a form to add players to the specified team.

get_form(request, obj=None, change=False, **kwargs)¶

Return a Form class for use in the admin add view. This is used by add_view and change_view.

Bases: django.apps.config.AppConfig

name = 'scheduler'¶

scheduler.decorators module¶

This module holds all the custom decorators for views that use it. This includes ensuring a user has the correct permissions to access certain views.

scheduler.decorators.is_team_admin_or_superuser(function)¶

:returns True if user is the admin of the team from function param or a superuser

scheduler.decorators.is_user_or_superuser(function)¶

:returns True if the user is the same specified in function params or a superuser

scheduler.forms module¶

Controls all the forms generated into HTML by django. This includes editing instances of models and validating data.

clean_battlenetID()¶

Checks the battlenetID isn’t already in use and follows blizzard’s battletag naming conventions: https://us.battle.net/support/en/article/26963

Returns

battlenetID after validating it is available and is a valid

battletag

clean_email()¶

Checks the email isn’t already in use

Returns

email after validating it is available

clean_username()¶

Checks the username isn’t already in use

Returns

username after validating it is available

scheduler.models module¶

This module controls django’s generated database. Each model determines an entity while each field corresponds to an attribute or relationship. This controls the information to be stored for each Player, Team, Match, and TimeSlot.

objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object>¶
player_set_1¶

Accessor to the related objects manager on the forward and reverse sides of a many-to-many relation.

In the example:

class Pizza(Model):
    toppings = ManyToManyField(Topping, related_name='pizzas')

Pizza.toppings and Topping.pizzas are ManyToManyDescriptor instances.

Most of the implementation is delegated to a dynamically defined manager class built by create_forward_many_to_many_manager() defined below.

team_1¶

Accessor to the related object on the forward side of a many-to-one or one-to-one (via ForwardOneToOneDescriptor subclass) relation.

In the example:

class Child(Model):
    parent = ForeignKey(Parent, related_name='children')

Child.parent is a ForwardManyToOneDescriptor instance.

class scheduler.models.Player(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: django.contrib.auth.models.AbstractUser

This is the model for Players (users) to store in the database. It uses django’s AbstractUser which already stores first name, last name, email, username, and password. This allows us to use django’s secure password hashing but still give our users attributes like university, role, battletag, sr, and team. The team in this model is an optional foreign key that can be null and/or blank. The default string for a player is their battletag. It also restricts the roles to either damage, tank, or support.

class scheduler.models.Team(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

The Team model identifies an ID and Alias as identifiers. Although teams can have the same alias, our database will need a unique ID for each.

class scheduler.models.TimeSlot(*args, **kwargs)¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

The model for TimeSlot allows users to set their availability. The ID avoids the composite key issue from django. Since they don’t allow composite keys, this is the next best option.

scheduler.tests module¶

Contains all the tests for scheduler. This includes the models and views.

scheduler.urls module¶

Includes all the definitions for urls related to the scheduler app

scheduler.urls.path(route, view, kwargs=None, name=None, *, Pattern=<class 'django.urls.resolvers.RoutePattern'>)¶

scheduler.views module¶

This file handles the connections between the server and client. The views provide information for the html files and handle redirection and rendering of templates. The views also ensure access protection for users, and require authentication on certain pages.

Allison Bickford 4/11/2019

class scheduler.views.PlayerAutoComplete(**kwargs)¶

Bases: dal_select2.views.Select2QuerySetView

handles autocomplete for players

get_queryset()¶

Filter the queryset with GET[‘q’].

class scheduler.views.TeamAutoComplete(**kwargs)¶

Bases: dal_select2.views.Select2QuerySetView

Extends the autocomplete plugin. Creates the parameters used to search for a team in PlayerChangeForm team field, which is a drop down search.

get_queryset()¶

Filter the queryset with GET[‘q’].

scheduler.views.create_match(request)¶

handles creating a match between teams.

Parameters

request – network session info

Returns

redirects to next step in creating a match, or access denied if

a user does not manage/admin any teams

scheduler.views.create_match_next(request, match_id)¶

Handles creating/editing optional details for a match. User must be an admin of either team.

Parameters

  • request – network session info

  • match_id – primary key of match to change

Returns

redirects to my teams on successful change, access denied if user

is not an admin, otherwise returns the create_match_next template

scheduler.views.create_team(request)¶

handles creating a team

Parameters

request – network session info

Returns

template with login context to create a team

scheduler.views.edit_match(request, match_id)¶

Handles changing a match’s teams and times. The user must be an admin of either team.

Parameters

  • request – network session info

  • match_id – primary key of match to edit

Returns

redirects to create_match_next, or access denied if not an admin

scheduler.views.handler403(request, exception=None, template_name='scheduler/access_denied.html')¶

using code adapted from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17662928 /django-creating-a-custom-500-404-error-page

scheduler.views.handler404(request, exception=None, template_name='scheduler/404.html')¶

using code adapted from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17662928 /django-creating-a-custom-500-404-error-page

scheduler.views.handler500(request, exception=None, template_name='scheduler/500.html')¶

using code adapted from https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17662928 /django-creating-a-custom-500-404-error-page

scheduler.views.home(request)¶

Home page

Parameters

request – network request info

Returns

template and variables to pass into it

scheduler.views.join_team(request, teamID, username)¶

Allows a user to join a team. Also provides a way for a superuser to add a player to a team without going through the admin page.

Parameters

  • request – network session info

  • teamID – primary key of team to join

  • username – username of player requesting to join team

Returns

redirect to my teams view

scheduler.views.leave_team(request, teamID, username)¶

Allows a user to leave a team. Allows a superuser to remove a player from their team. This can be used later to allow team leaders to remove players.

Parameters

  • request – network session info

  • teamID – primary key of team to get removed from

  • username – username of the player to remove from team

Returns

redirects to team page for users and superusers, while admins are

redirected to their admin page

scheduler.views.login_context(request)¶

view that handles logging in the current user and returning the context

Parameters

request – network request info, such as user

:returns dict containing login form, authenticated user,

teams, and teams user admins

scheduler.views.player_profile(request, username)¶

displays the profile page for a player by username the battletag doesn’t work in url so the username is another key we can use to identify the player

Parameters

  • request – network request info

  • username – username of the players whose profile to view

scheduler.views.players(request)¶

Goes to the players page using the list of players sorted by battletags and uses the player search bar to generate the list of players matching the search.

Parameters

request – network request info

Returns

login context and list of all players

scheduler.views.register(request)¶

view to add a new user and log them in. Redirects on successful user creation or shows form errors if the input was not valid.

Parameters

request – network session info

Returns

access denied if user is logged in, otherwise the register

template

scheduler.views.team_profile(request, teamID)¶

displays the profile page for a team and their relevant information

Parameters

  • request – network session info

  • teamID – primary key of team to view profile of

Returns

template with information about the requested team

scheduler.views.teams(request)¶

displays the page that lists all the teams, sorted by their teamID. This also implements searching for teams by their name or id.

Parameters

request – HttpRequest with network info

Returns

template for teams with login context and list of all teams

scheduler.views.user_logout(request)¶

view that handles logging out the current user. Redirects to previous page after, or home if it can’t.
